facts.text: Subordinate Judge at Monghyr judgment dated 27th November 1945 in Title Suit No. 34 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Judge at Monghyr in Title Suit No. 34 of 1944. C. Issacs  Ganeshwar Prasad and R. C. Prasad, with him  for the appellants. B.K. Saran and M. M. Sinha

facts.text: Appellants instituted suit in Court of Subordinate Judge Monghyr for possession of 12 acres 51 cents land in mauza Bardih.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Monghyr, for recovery of possession of 12 acres 51 cents of land situated in mauza Bardih, of which defendants Nos. 12 and 13,

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 12 and 13 are proprietors of the land in mauza Bardih.

anchor.surface_text: mauza Bardih, of which defendants Nos. 12 and 13, forming the second party, are the proprietors. The allegations in the plaint are that on 12th April,

facts.text: On 12th April 1943, plaintiffs were admitted by second party as occupancy tenants on payment of Rs. 1950 salami and put into possession.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in the plaint are that on 12th April, 1943, the plaintiffs were admitted by the second party as occupancy tenants on payment of a sum of Rs. 1,950 as salami and put into possession of the. lands,

facts.text: First party defendants Nos. 1 to 11 trespassed on the lands and carried away the crops.

anchor.surface_text: and that thereafter, the first party companysisting of defendants Nos. 1 to 11 trespassed on them and carried away the crops. The, suit was accordingly laid for ejecting defendants Nos. I to II and for mesne profits,

facts.text: Suit valued at Rs. 2,950 for possession Rs. 1,950 and past mesne profits Rs. 1,000.

anchor.surface_text: past and future, and it was valued at Rs. 2,950, made up of Rs. 1,950 being the value of the relief for possession and Rs. 1,000, being the past mesne profits claimed. Defendants Nos.- I to II companytested the suit.

facts.text: Defendants 1-11 pleaded possession as tenants on batai from fasli 1336 and acquired occupancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: They pleaded that they had been in possession of the lands as tenants on batai system, sharing the produce with the landlord., from fasli 1336 and had acquired occupancy rights in the tenements, that the second party had numberright to settle them on the plaintiffs,

facts.text: Settlement dated 12th April 1943 conferred no rights on plaintiffs according to defendants 1-11.

anchor.surface_text: that the latter acquired numberrights under the settlement dated 12th April, 1943. Defendants Nos. 12 and 13 remained ex-parte. The Subordinate Judge held, relying on certain receipts

facts.text: Defendants 12 and 13 remained ex-parte.

anchor.surface_text: 1943. Defendants Nos. 12 and 13 remained ex-parte. The Subordinate Judge held, relying on certain receipts marked as Exhibits A to A-114 which were in the handwriting of the patwaris

facts.text: Subordinate Judge relied on receipts Exhibits A to A-114 from fasli 1336 to 1347, held defendants 1-11 had possession over 12 years as tenants, acquired occupancy rights, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held, relying on certain receipts marked as Exhibits A to A-114 which were in the handwriting of the patwaris of the second party and which ranged over the period from fasli 1336 to 1347, that defendants Nos. I to II had been in possession for over 12 years as cultivating tenants and had acquired occupancy rights,

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed to District Judge Monghyr, who agreed receipts genuine and occupancy rights acquired, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly dismissed the suit. The plaintiffs preferred an appeal against this decision to the Court of the District Judge. Monghyr, who agreed with the trial Court that the receipts, Exhibits A to A-114 were genuine, and that defendants Nos. I to 11 had acquired occupancy rights, and accordingly dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: In second appeal S.A. No. 1152 of 1946 to High Court Patna, Stamp Reporter objected to plaint valuation, court determined correct valuation Rs. 9,980.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs took up the matter in second appeal to the High Court, Patna, S.A. No. 1152 of 1946, and there, for the first time an objection was taken by the Stamp Reporter to the valuation in the plaint and after enquiry, the Court determined that the companyrect valuation of the suit was Rs. 9,980.

facts.text: Plaintiffs paid additional court-fees on revised valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs paid the additional Court-fees required of them, and then raised the companytention that on the revised valuation, the appeal from the decree of the Subordinater Judge would lie number to the District Court but to the High Court,

facts.text: High Court held appeal to District Court competent following Ramdeo Singh v. Raj Narain, no prejudice shown, dismissed second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held following the decision of a Full -Bench of that Court in Ramdeo Singh v. Raj Narain  1 , that the appeal to the District Court was companypetent, and that its decision companyld be reversed only if the appellants companyld establish prejudice on the merits, and holding that on a companysideration of the evidence numbersuch prejudice had been shown, they dismissed the second appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 14 April 1954 by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. April 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-This appeal raises a question on the companystruction of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

facts.text: Proper court for suit is Subordinate Court Monghyr whether valuation Rs 2950 or Rs 9980, but affects appeal forum.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the proper Court to try the present action would be the Subordinate Court, Monghyr, whether the valuation of the suit was Rs. 2,950 as given in the plaint, or Rs. 9,880 as determined by the High Court but it will make a difference in the forum to which the appeal from its judgment would lie,

facts.text: On plaint valuation Rs 2950, appeal lies to District Court; on Rs 9980 to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: whether the one valuation or the other is to be accepted as the deciding factor. On the plaint valuation, the appeal would lie to the District Court on the valuation as determined by the High Court, it is that Court that would be companypetent to entertain the appeal.

facts.text: District Court lacked jurisdiction on true valuation, its decree nullity argued by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants is that as on the valuation of the suit as ultimately determined, the District Court was number companypetent to entertain the appeal, the decree and judgment passed by that Court must be treated as a nullity,

facts.text: Supreme Court held decree of District Court not nullity under section 11 Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants, therefore, that the decree and judgment of the District Court, Monghyr, should be treated as a nullity cannot be sustained under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

facts.text: No prejudice suffered by appellants as appeal heard fully by District Court on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Even apart from this, we are satisfied that numberprejudice was caused to the appellants by their appeal having been heard by the District Court. There was a fair and full hearing of the appeal by that Court it gave its decision on the merits on a companysideration of the entire evidence in the case,

issues.text: Whether a decree passed by a court lacking jurisdiction due to under-valuation of the suit/appeal is a nullity, or whether section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act overrides the general principle of nullity and requires objections to be entertained only on showing prejudice on merits?

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-This appeal raises a question on the construction of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act. The appellants instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Monghyr, for recovery of possession of 12 acres 51 cents of land situated in mauza Bardih,

issues.text: Whether the appellants suffered prejudice within the meaning of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act merely because their appeal was heard by the District Court instead of the High Court due to under-valuation?

anchor.surface_text: And alternatively, it is contended that even if the decree and judgment of the District Court on appeal are not to be treated as a nullity and the matter is to be dealt with under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act, the appellants had suffered Prejudice within the meaning of that section, in that their appeal against the judgment of the Subordinate Judge was heard not by the High Court but by a Court of inferior jurisdiction, viz., the District Court of Monghyr,

issues.text: Whether, for determining prejudice under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act, the second appellate court must re-examine the findings of fact recorded by the lower appellate court as in a first appeal?

anchor.surface_text: It is next argued that in the view that the decree of the lower appellate Court is liable to be reversed only on proof of prejudice on the merits, the second appellate Court must, for the purpose of ascertaining whether there was prejudice, hear the appeal fully on the facts, and that, in effect, it should be Heard as a first appeal. Reliance is placed in support of this contention on the observations of two of the learned Judges in Ramdeo Singh v. Rai Narain

issues.text: Whether there was any prejudice on merits caused to the appellants by the under-valuation leading to the appeal being heard by the District Court?

anchor.surface_text: 1954. April 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-This appeal raises a question on the construction of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

arguments.claim: General principle decree without jurisdiction nullity does not apply due to section 11 Suits Valuation Act which is self-contained provision for valuation objections.

anchor.surface_text: It is a fundamental principle well established that a decree passed by a Court without jurisdiction is a nullity, and that its invalidity could be set up whenever and wherever it is sought to be enforced or relied upon, even at the stage of execution

arguments.claim: Rajlakshmi Dasee v Katyayani Dasee and Shidappa Venkatrao v Rachappa Subrao do not support nullity as section 11 not considered; facts different.

arguments.claim: Mere change of forum due to under-valuation not prejudice under section 11; per Full Benches Kelu Achan, Mool Chand, Ramdeo Singh.

anchor.surface_text: that mere change of forum is not a prejudice within the meaning of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act. Vide Kelu Achan v. Cheriya Parvathi Nethiar  1 , Mool Chand v. Ram Kishan  2  and Ramdeo Singh y. Baj Narain  3 .

arguments.claim: Right of appeal not deprived; under-valuation gave extra appeal stage; change of forum not prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The right of appeal is no doubt a substantive right, and its deprivation is a serious prejudice but the appellants have not been deprived of the right of appeal against the judgment of the Subordinate Court.

arguments.claim: To ascertain prejudice under s11, second appellate court need not rehear as first appeal on facts; errors in fact findings not prejudice attributable to valuation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Prejudice must be directly from valuation; s103 CPC not applicable as findings recorded.

arguments.claim: Plaintiffs who chose valuation cannot later complain of jurisdiction/prejudice; estoppel-like principle.
No prejudice caused; full fair hearing by District Court on merits; no injustice.

anchor.surface_text: Even apart from this, we are satisfied that no prejudice was caused to the appellants by their appeal having been heard by the District Court. There was a fair and full hearing of the appeal by that Court it gave its decision on the merits

holdings.text: The contention of the appellants, therefore, that the decree and judgment of the District Court, Monghyr, should be treated as a nullity cannot be sustained under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants, therefore, that the decree and judgment of the District Court, Monghyr, should be treated as a nullity cannot be sustained under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 11 SVA is self-contained code overriding general nullity principle for pecuniary jurisdiction defects due to valuation; policy against technical reversals without prejudice on merits; distinguishes cases not considering s11; analogous to CPC s21, s99.

holdings.text: Mere change of forum due to under-valuation does not constitute prejudice within the meaning of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The complaint of the appellants really is not that they had been deprived of a right of appeal against the judgment of the Subordinate Court, which they have not been, but that an appeal on the facts against that judgment was heard by the District Court and not by the High ,Court. This objection therefore amounts to this that a change in the forum of appeal is by itself a matter of prejudice for the purpose of section 1 1 of the Suits Valuation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of s11 requires prejudice affecting disposal on merits, not mere forum change; follows Full Bench precedents (Kelu Achan, Mool Chand, Ramdeo Singh); under-valuation enlarged appeal rights; otherwise s11 words otiose.

holdings.text: An appellate Court has no power under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act to consider whether the findings of fact recorded by the lower appellate Court are correct, and error in those findings cannot be held to be prejudice within the meaning of that section.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prejudice must be directly attributable to valuation error, not general fact errors; s11 not convert second appeal to first; s103 CPC inapplicable as findings recorded; rejects Ramdeo Singh observations requiring full fact rehearing.

holdings.text: No prejudice was caused to the appellants by their appeal having been heard by the District Court; there was a fair and full hearing on merits with no injustice.

anchor.surface_text: Even apart from this, we are satisfied that no prejudice was caused to the appellants by their appeal having been heard by the District Court. There was a fair and full hearing of the appeal by that Court it gave its decision on the merits on a consideration of the entire evidence in the case, and no injustice is shown to have resulted in its disposal of the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full merits hearing by District Court; no injustice; appellants chose valuation, invoked jurisdiction, cannot complain (estoppel principle); prejudice must result from others' acts, exercised cautiously as revisional jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The decision of the learned Judges that there were no grounds for interference under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court application of s11; no nullity, no prejudice on any ground.

Concept c5 stating S11 SVA modifies Section 99 CPC's lack of protection supports holding h1's conclusion that nullity contention fails under S11 SVA.
Concept c5 on Section 99 CPC and its modification by S11 SVA directly addresses the issue i1 of whether undervaluation jurisdiction decrees are nullities or overridden by S11 SVA.
Section 100 CPC limitations on second appeals support the holding by reinforcing that second appellate courts do not re-examine facts, even in valuation contexts under the Suits Valuation Act.

Section 100 CPC, imposing limitations on second appeals such as not converting to first appeal due to valuation, addresses the issue concerning the second appellate court's role in re-examining facts for prejudice under section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act.

Description of c7 states Section 103 CPC applies only if lower court failed to record finding on issue and not for re-examining facts in s11 context, which provides the legal basis grounding the holding h3 that appellate court has no power under s11 to consider correctness of fact findings.

edges.explanation: Analogy between S21 CPC territorial jurisdiction and s11 SVA pecuniary jurisdiction addresses the issue of what constitutes prejudice from forum change.

The fact of the Stamp Reporter's objection to plaint valuation in second appeal S.A. No. 1152 of 1946 and the court's determination of correct valuation Rs. 9,980 triggers the application of Section 100 CPC limitations on second appeals, including not converting to first appeal due to valuation.

The fact that the High Court determined valuation in the second appeal without indicated re-examination of lower findings supports the holding that appellate courts lack power under section 11 to assess correctness of fact findings.

anchor.surface_text: The complaint of the appellants really is not that they had been deprived of a right of appeal against the judgment of the Subordinate Court, which they have not been, but that an appeal on the facts against that judgment was heard by the District Court and not by the High ,Court. This objection therefore amounts to this that a change in the forum of appeal is by itself a matter of prejudice for the purpose of section 1 1 of the Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Even apart from this, we are satisfied that no prejudice was caused to the appellants by their appeal having been heard by the District Court.
